{{cpp/title|begin&lt;small&gt;(std::valarray)&lt;/small&gt;}}
{{cpp/numeric/valarray/navbar}}
{{dcl begin}}
{{dcl|num=1|since=c++11|
template&lt; class T &gt; 
/* see below */ begin( valarray&lt;T&gt;&amp; v );
}}
{{dcl|num=2|since=c++11|
template&lt; class T &gt; 
/* see below */ begin( const valarray&lt;T&gt;&amp; v );
}}
{{dcl end}}

The overload of {{lc|std::begin}} for {{tt|valarray}} returns an iterator of unspecified type referring to the first element in the numeric array. 

@1@ The return type must
* meet the requirements of [[cpp/iterator|mutable]] {{named req|RandomAccessIterator}},
{{rrev|since=c++20|* model {{lconcept|contiguous_iterator}},}}
* have a member type {{tt|value_type}}, which is {{tt|T}}, and
* have a member type {{tt|reference}}, which is {{tt|T&amp;}}.
@2@ The return type must
* meet the requirements of [[cpp/iterator|constant]] {{named req|RandomAccessIterator}},
{{rrev|since=c++20|* model {{lconcept|contiguous_iterator}},}}
* have a member type {{tt|value_type}}, which is {{tt|T}}, and
* have a member type {{tt|reference}}, which is {{tt|const T&amp;}}.

The iterator returned from this function is invalidated when the member function {{rlpf|resize}} is called on {{c|v}} or when the lifetime of {{c|v}} ends, whichever comes first.

===Parameters===
{{par begin}}
{{par|v|a numeric array}}
{{par end}} 

===Return value===
Iterator to the first value in the numeric array.

{{cpp/impldef exception}}

===Notes===
Unlike other functions that take {{tt|std::valarray}} arguments, {{tt|begin()}} cannot accept the replacement types (such as the types produced by expression templates) that may be returned from expressions involving valarrays: {{c|std::begin(v1 + v2)}} is not portable, {{c|std::begin(std::valarray&lt;T&gt;(v1 + v2))}} has to be used instead.

The intent of this function is to allow [[cpp/language/range-for|range for loops]] to work with valarrays, not to provide container semantics.

===Example===
{{example
|code=
#include &lt;algorithm&gt;
#include &lt;iostream&gt;
#include &lt;valarray&gt;

void show(const std::valarray&lt;int&gt;&amp; v)
{
    std::for_each(std::begin(v), std::end(v), [](int c)
    {
        std::cout &lt;&lt; c &lt;&lt; ' ';
    });
    std::cout &lt;&lt; '\n';
};

int main()
{
    const std::valarray&lt;int&gt; x{47, 70, 37, 52, 90, 23, 17, 33, 22, 16, 21, 4};
    const std::valarray&lt;int&gt; y{25, 31, 71, 56, 21, 21, 15, 34, 21, 27, 12, 6};

    show(x); 
    show(y); 

    const std::valarray&lt;int&gt; z{x + y};

    for (char c : z)
        std::cout &lt;&lt; c;
}
|output=
47 70 37 52 90 23 17 33 22 16 21 4 
25 31 71 56 21 21 15 34 21 27 12 6 
Hello, C++!
}}
